title: Weapon Training - Rifle Characteristics, Handling and Firing Techniques
description: Comprehensive test on .22 rifle and 7.62mm SLR characteristics, stripping, assembling, firing procedures, and range safety

questions.text: What is the effective range of .22 rifle?
questions.explanation: The effective range of .22 rifle is 25 yards as per NCC training standards.

questions.text: Which rifle is described as 'Self Loading' in NCC training?
questions.explanation: 7.62mm SLR is described as 'Self Loading' as it automatically loads the next round after firing.

questions.text: What is the magazine capacity of 7.62mm SLR?
questions.explanation: The 7.62mm SLR has a magazine capacity of 20 rounds.

questions.text: What is the first step in stripping .22 rifle?
questions.explanation: When stripping .22 rifle, first remove the bayonet, then sling, bolt, and finally case collector.

questions.text: What is the normal rate of fire for 7.62mm SLR?
questions.explanation: The normal rate of fire for 7.62mm SLR is 5 rounds per minute.

questions.text: Which position is considered the basic and comfortable firing position?
questions.explanation: Lying position is considered the basic, comfortable, and fundamental firing position that provides stability.

questions.text: What does 'MPI' stand for in shooting terminology?
questions.explanation: MPI stands for 'Mean Point of Impact' - the central point of a group of shots fired at the same aiming point.

questions.text: What is the purpose of 'Snap Shooting' training?

options.b: To fire at targets visible for short duration

questions.explanation: Snap shooting involves firing at targets that appear for very short durations, requiring quick aiming and firing.

questions.text: What should be checked before stripping any rifle?
questions.explanation: Before stripping, ensure the rifle is empty and safety catch is in 'S' position for safety.

questions.text: How many grooves are there in .22 rifle barrel?
questions.explanation: Both .22 rifle models have 6 grooves in the barrel.

questions.text: What is the weight of 7.62mm SLR without magazine?
questions.explanation: The 7.62mm SLR weighs 4.4 kg without magazine.

questions.text: Which part of the finger should be used for trigger operation?
questions.explanation: The area between first and second joint of the index finger should be used for proper trigger control.

questions.text: What is 'Follow Through' in shooting?
questions.explanation: Follow through means maintaining the same position, hold, and sight picture from shot firing until calling 'maar'.

questions.text: What color flag indicates 'Firing in Progress' on range?
questions.explanation: A red flag (6'x6') on a 20' pole indicates firing is in progress on the range.

questions.text: How many rounds are used for grouping practice?
questions.explanation: Five rounds fired at the same aiming point are used to determine grouping capacity.

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of cleaning rifle after firing?

options.b: To prevent rust and ensure functioning

questions.explanation: Regular cleaning prevents rust, ensures proper functioning, and maintains weapon reliability.

questions.text: Which shooting principle emphasizes 'One Bullet One Enemy'?
questions.explanation: Snap shooting follows the principle 'One Bullet One Enemy' and 'Shoot to Kill'.

questions.text: What should be the muzzle direction when handling weapons on range?
questions.explanation: Muzzle should always be pointed in a safe direction, away from personnel, when handling weapons.

questions.text: What is 'Zeroing' of a rifle?

options.b: Adjusting sights so MPI matches POA

questions.explanation: Zeroing is adjusting sights so that the Mean Point of Impact coincides with the Point of Aim.

questions.text: How often should weekly cleaning of weapons be done?
questions.explanation: Weekly cleaning should be done once a week where all parts are oiled and checked.

questions.text: What is the maximum range of .22 rifle at 33 degree angle?
questions.explanation: The maximum range of .22 rifle when fired at 33 degree angle is 1700 yards.

questions.text: Which tool is used for extracting stuck cases?
questions.explanation: Special tool for removing ruptured cases is used to extract stuck cartridge cases from chamber.

questions.text: What is the correct procedure when a rifle fails to fire?
questions.explanation: When rifle fails to fire, wait 30 seconds keeping it aimed at target, then unload carefully.

questions.text: What does 'Sight Picture' refer to?
questions.explanation: Sight Picture is the correct alignment of sights with the target point of aim.

questions.text: How many details work simultaneously on firing range?
questions.explanation: Four details work simultaneously: one firing detail, two waiting details, and one ammunition collection detail.

questions.text: What is the purpose of 'Tin Disc' exercise?
questions.explanation: Tin Disc exercise is used to practice trigger control without disturbing the rifle's aim.

questions.text: Which position provides the smallest body profile?
questions.explanation: Lying position provides the smallest body profile, offering best protection from enemy fire.

questions.text: What should be done if MPI is above POA?
questions.explanation: If MPI is above POA, raise the foresight to lower the point of impact.

questions.text: What is the normal pace for NCC cadets in 'Tez Chal'?
questions.explanation: NCC cadets march at 116 steps per minute, while rifle units march at 140 steps.

questions.text: Which safety rule is most important on firing range?
questions.explanation: Weapon must always be pointed down range in safe direction, with muzzle control being paramount.

questions.text: What is the weight of .22 Deluxe BA rifle?
questions.explanation: .22 Deluxe BA rifle weighs 6 Lbs 2 OZ, lighter than .22 No II MK IV which weighs 8 Lbs 10Â½ OZ.

questions.text: How many stages are there in Snap Shooting training?
questions.explanation: Snap shooting training has 5 stages progressing from basic alignment to timed target practice.

questions.text: What is the purpose of 'Natural Alignment' in firing position?
questions.explanation: Natural alignment minimizes muscle strain, provides comfort, and helps maintain steady aim.

questions.text: Which cleaning material is used for barrel?
questions.explanation: Chindi (cloth pieces) and pull through are used for barrel cleaning with appropriate oil.

questions.text: What does 'R' position on safety catch indicate?
questions.explanation: 'R' position on safety catch means 'Ready' or fire position, while 'S' means 'Safe'.

questions.text: How long should warm water cleaning be done after firing?
questions.explanation: After firing, warm water cleaning should be done for at least 7 days to remove powder residue.

questions.text: What is the primary consideration in trigger operation?
questions.explanation: Trigger should be pressed with smooth, steady pressure without disturbing rifle alignment.

questions.text: Which document records firing point activities?
questions.explanation: Butt Register, Firing Point Register, and Ammunition Register all document range activities.

questions.text: What is the correct breathing technique during aiming?
questions.explanation: Breathe normally during aiming, only pausing briefly during final trigger squeeze.

questions.text: What indicates a good grouping?
questions.explanation: Good grouping shows shots closely clustered together, indicating consistent aiming and firing.

questions.text: Which part of SLR operates using gas pressure?
questions.explanation: SLR uses gas operation where gas pressure drives piston and slide to automate loading.

questions.text: What is the first action when weapon misfires?
questions.explanation: When weapon misfires, wait 30 seconds keeping it aimed at target before unloading.

questions.text: How many types of rifle cleaning are mentioned?
questions.explanation: Six types of cleaning: Daily, Weekly, Monthly, Before firing, During firing, and After firing.

questions.text: What is the purpose of 'Aiming Correcter'?
questions.explanation: Aiming correcter is used to check and correct sight alignment during training.

questions.text: What should be worn by sentries on firing range?
questions.explanation: Sentries on firing range wear red coats for high visibility and safety identification.

questions.text: What is the correct way to carry weapon between firing points?
questions.explanation: Weapon should be carried at trail (pointing down) when moving between firing points.

questions.text: Which factor most affects shooting accuracy?
questions.explanation: Shooter's technique including position, hold, sight alignment and trigger control most affects accuracy.

questions.text: What is the final step in rifle assembly?
questions.explanation: Bayonet is fitted last after all other parts including sling and magazine are assembled.

questions.text: What does 'HPS' stand for in scoring?
questions.explanation: HPS stands for 'Highest Possible Score' - the maximum score achievable in a practice.

questions.text: What is the most important safety rule during weapon handling?
questions.explanation: All options are fundamental safety rules: treat weapons as loaded, keep finger off trigger, and use safety catch.
